snippet: This year, the people who actually own public companies are gaining some influence over corporate executive pay practices, via say-on-pay votes.
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column welcomes evidence that shareholders of public companies are gaining some influence over corporate executive pay practices via say-on-pay votes, a result of the Dodd-Frank law; concedes that votes are not binding, but notes that some companies are listening and responding with changes.
lead_paragraph: This year, the people who actually own public companies are gaining some influence over corporate executive pay practices, via say-on-pay votes.

headline.seo: Say-on-Pay Votes Make More Shareholder Voices Heard
headline.main: When Shareholders Make Their Voices Heard
headline.print_headline: A Rich Game of Thrones: At Last, Signs That Shareholders Are Making Their Voices Heard

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
